elements.content: The reaction of uranyl nitrate with (1R,3S)-(+)-camphoric acid (H2L) in the presence of 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) gives the chiral octanuclear cage [(UO2)8(L12H8)]·12H2O (1), which displays an approximately cubic shape with the metal ions as apexes and an internal cavity of ca. 7 Å in length. Complex 1, which is the first example of a homoleptic nanosized cage including uranyl ions, can further be used as a supramolecular building block to generate coordination polymers, as exemplified by the compound [Ba(H2O)8]2[(UO2)8Ba2(L12)(H2O)4]·8H2O (2), obtained in the presence of Ba(CH3COO)2. In 2, which retains the overall packing mode of cages present in 1, a two-dimensional assembly is formed through bridging by the carboxylate-bound alkaline-earth metal cations. However, whereas 1 displays extended channels, these are obstructed by counterions in 2.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of uranyl nitrate with (1R,3S)-(+)-camphoric acid (H2L) in the presence of 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) gives the chiral octanuclear cage [(UO2)8(L12H8)]⋅12H2O (1), which displays an approximately cubic shape with the metal ions as apexes and an internal cavity of ca. 7 Å in length. Complex 1, which is the first example of a homoleptic nanosized cage including uranyl ions, can further be used as a supramolecular building block to generate coordination polymers, as exemplified by the compound [Ba(H2O)8]2[(UO2)8Ba2(L12)(H2O)4]⋅8H2O (2), obtained in the presence of Ba(CH3COO)2. In 2, which retains the overall packing mode of cages present in 1, a two-dimensional assembly is formed through bridging by the carboxylate-bound alkaline-earth metal cations. However, whereas 1 displays extended channels, these are obstructed by counterions in 2.

elements.content: The pseudocubic cages built from 8 uranyl ions and 12 (1R,3S)-(+)-camphorate ligands can be used as supramolecular building units and assembled into a two-dimensional framework by bridging alkaline-earth metal cations.
elements.clean_text: The pseudocubic cages built from 8 uranyl ions and 12 (1R,3S)-(+)-camphorate ligands can be used as supramolecular building units and assembled into a two-dimensional framework by bridging alkaline-earth metal cations.

elements.content: The linear geometry of the uranyl ion [UO2]2+ enforces an equatorial positioning of the ligands in its complexes, which results in the marked propensity of this ion to form one- or two-dimensional materials. However, this trend can be overcome and three-dimensional frameworks can be obtained, for example, by using flexible, multifunctional ligands or cation−cation interactions involving the uranyl oxo atoms. Uranyl-containing assemblies, either discrete or polymeric, displaying original topologies have also been reported in the past few years, such as nanotubules and nanospheres. In particular, rigid ditopic ligands presenting a suitable curvature were used to build a series of cyclic molecular complexes. Either a monoester derivative of the cis,trans epimer of Kemp’s triacid or a bis(catecholate) ligand gave octanuclear cages, including also μ-peroxo bridging ions, whereas (2R,3R,4S,5S)-tetrahydrofurantetracarboxylic acid was used to obtain tri- and tetranuclear metallacycles. The tetratopic ligand 1,2,3,4-cyclobutanetetracarboxylate in the trans,trans,trans form, which presents a double curvature, yielded a three-dimensional cubic framework comprising tetranuclear metallacycles and octanuclear cages as subunits and displaying large channels. (1R,3S)-(+)-Camphoric acid (denoted H2L hereafter) appeared as a promising ligand in this context, with its two carboxylic acid groups presenting a suitable angle, but first attempts at synthesis of uranyl complexes, in pyridine or methanol, only gave one- or two-dimensional chiral assemblies. However, two novel uranyl camphorate complexes have now been obtained under hydrothermal conditions, and crystallographically characterized, which display the expected formation of a cyclic structure and are described herein.
elements.clean_text: The linear geometry of the uranyl ion [UO2]2+ enforces an equatorial positioning of the ligands in its complexes, which results in the marked propensity of this ion to form one- or two-dimensional materials. However, this trend can be overcome and three-dimensional frameworks can be obtained, for example, by using flexible, multifunctional ligands or cation-cation interactions involving the uranyl oxo atoms. Uranyl-containing assemblies, either discrete or polymeric, displaying original topologies have also been reported in the past few years, such as nanotubules and nanospheres. In particular, rigid ditopic ligands presenting a suitable curvature were used to build a series of cyclic molecular complexes. Either a monoester derivative of the cis,trans epimer of Kemp's triacid or a bis(catecholate) ligand gave octanuclear cages, including also μ-peroxo bridging ions, whereas (2R,3R,4S,5S)-tetrahydrofurantetracarboxylic acid was used to obtain tri- and tetranuclear metallacycles. The tetratopic ligand 1,2,3,4-cyclobutanetetracarboxylate in the trans,trans,trans form, which presents a double curvature, yielded a three-dimensional cubic framework comprising tetranuclear metallacycles and octanuclear cages as subunits and displaying large channels. (1R,3S)-(+)-Camphoric acid (denoted H2L hereafter) appeared as a promising ligand in this context, with its two carboxylic acid groups presenting a suitable angle, but first attempts at synthesis of uranyl complexes, in pyridine or methanol, only gave one- or two-dimensional chiral assemblies. However, two novel uranyl camphorate complexes have now been obtained under hydrothermal conditions, and crystallographically characterized, which display the expected formation of a cyclic structure and are described herein.

elements.content: The two complexes [(UO2)8(L12H8)]·12H2O (1) and [Ba(H2O)8]2[(UO2)8Ba2(L12)(H2O)4]·8H2O (2) crystallize in the same chiral space group I4, with nearly identical unit cell parameters. Isomorphous crystals were also obtained with other reactants, such as NMe4OH instead of DABCO or Sr2+ in place of Ba2+, and also in the presence of the alkali metal ions K+ and Rb+, but the crystal quality was too low in these cases. The same octanuclear cage is present in both compounds, and it will be described in the case of the simplest species, [(UO2)8(L12H8)]·12H2O (1).
elements.clean_text: The two complexes [(UO2)8(L12H8)]⋅12H2O (1) and [Ba(H2O)8]2[(UO2)8Ba2(L12)(H2O)4]⋅8H2O (2) crystallize in the same chiral space group I4, with nearly identical unit cell parameters. Isomorphous crystals were also obtained with other reactants, such as NMe4OH instead of DABCO or Sr2+ in place of Ba2+, and also in the presence of the alkali metal ions K+ and Rb+, but the crystal quality was too low in these cases. The same octanuclear cage is present in both compounds, and it will be described in the case of the simplest species, [(UO2)8(L12H8)]⋅12H2O (1).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit in 1 contains two uranyl ions and three (1R,3S)-(+)-camphorate ligands (Figure ). Two protons, which were not found and must be disordered over several positions, necessarily remain for charge equilibrium. The uranyl ions are bound to three chelating carboxylate groups, with the usual hexagonal bipyramidal environment geometry and an unexceptional average U−O bond length of 2.46(3) Å [2.45(4) Å for chelating camphorates in the previous complexes]. Each ligand bridges two uranyl ions, with dihedral angles between the carboxylate COO groups in the range 113.8(13)−119.3(13)°, close to the values of 116.6−118.1° in the free molecule and the previous complexes. The distance between the atoms U1 and U2 separated by the central ligand in the asymmetric unit is 9.2606(8) Å, whereas the distances between the uranium atoms linked by the lateral ligands are 9.7290(8) and 9.7845(7) Å. The dihedral angles between the equatorial planes of adjacent uranyl ions are 96.32(14)° around the central ligand and 115.60(18) and 117.05(17)° around the lateral ligands.

Two protons, which were not found and must be disordered over several positions, necessarily remain for charge equilibrium. The uranyl ions are bound to three chelating carboxylate groups, with the usual hexagonal bipyramidal environment geometry and an unexceptional average U-O bond length of 2.46(3) Å [2.45(4) Å for chelating camphorates in the previous complexes]. Each ligand bridges two uranyl ions, with dihedral angles between the carboxylate COO groups in the range 113.8(13)-119.3(13)°, close to the values of 116.6-118.1° in the free molecule and the previous complexes. The distance between the atoms U1 and U2 separated by the central ligand in the asymmetric unit is 9.2606(8) Å, whereas the distances between the uranium atoms linked by the lateral ligands are 9.7290(8) and 9.7845(7) Å. The dihedral angles between the equatorial planes of adjacent uranyl ions are 96.32(14)° around the central ligand and 115.60(18) and 117.05(17)° around the lateral ligands.

elements.content: View of the uranium atoms environment in 1. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 20% probability level. Hydrogen atoms are omitted. Symmetry codes: ′ = 1 − y, 1 + x, z; ′′ = y − 1, 1 − x, z. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): U1−O1 1.791(9), U1−O2 1.700(11), U1−O5 2.397(9), U1−O6 2.502(7), U1−O9 2.445(8), U1−O10 2.482(9), U1−O11′ 2.458(9), U1−O12′ 2.453(9), U2−O3 1.733(8), U2−O4 1.791(7), U2−O7 2.487(8), U2−O8 2.493(9), U2−O13 2.459(7), U2−O14 2.472(8), U2−O15′′ 2.416(9), U2−O16′′ 2.437(7), O1−U1−O2 178.3(4), O5−U1−O6 54.9(3), O6−U1−O9 68.8(3), O9−U1−O10 53.5(3), O10−U1−O11′ 64.7(3), O11′−U1−O12′ 51.9(3), O12′−U1−O5 66.6(3), O3−U2−O4 177.8(4), O7−U2−O8 52.3(3), O8−U2−O13 65.8(3), O13−U2−O14 53.5(3), O14−U2−O15′′ 69.7(3), O15′′−U2−O16′′ 52.4(3), O16′′−U2−O7 66.5(3).

These angles are convenient for ring closure, and slightly compressed pseudocubic octanuclear cages are formed, with the metal atoms as apexes and the 12 ligands along the sides (Figure ). These cages differ from those previously obtained by the absence of μ-peroxo bridges, likely as a result of different reaction conditions (the earlier complexes were synthesized in organic solvents at room temperature). The internal cavity has a side length of ca. 7 Å (ca. 4 Å when van der Waals radii are taken into account), but the entrance size is limited by the protruding methyl groups (Figure ). Water molecules could be located inside, where the uranyl oxo groups pointing inward are potential hydrogen bond acceptors, but none has been found in the structure and, if present, they are likely to be highly disordered. The cages are arranged side-by-side to form layers in the ab plane, with hydrogen bonding mediated by the solvent water molecules. Successive layers along c are related by (1/2, 1/2, 1/2) translations so that channels parallel to c are formed, with the cavities of the cages in one layer coinciding with the intermolecular spaces in its neighbors (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: These angles are convenient for ring closure, and slightly compressed pseudocubic octanuclear cages are formed, with the metal atoms as apexes and the 12 ligands along the sides (Figure ). These cages differ from those previously obtained by the absence of μ-peroxo bridges, likely as a result of different reaction conditions (the earlier complexes were synthesized in organic solvents at room temperature). The internal cavity has a side length of ca. 7 Å (ca. 4 Å when van der Waals radii are taken into account), but the entrance size is limited by the protruding methyl groups (Figure ). Water molecules could be located inside, where the uranyl oxo groups pointing inward are potential hydrogen bond acceptors, but none has been found in the structure and, if present, they are likely to be highly disordered. The cages are arranged side-by-side to form layers in the ab plane, with hydrogen bonding mediated by the solvent water molecules. Successive layers along c are related by (1/2, 1/2, 1/2) translations so that channels parallel to c are formed, with the cavities of the cages in one layer coinciding with the intermolecular spaces in its neighbors (Figure ).

elements.content: The addition of alkali or alkaline-earth metal cations to uranyl−organic complexes or coordination polymers is a means of increasing the dimensionality through bonding to the uranyl oxo groups or the ligands. Although it was attempted in the present system primarily to try to get better crystals, it resulted in the isolation of compound 2, which comprises the octanuclear cage [(UO2)8L12]8−, now devoid of remaining protons and with bond lengths and angles identical to those in 1, but which is now part of a cation-bridged two-dimensional assembly. Two barium atoms per octanuclear cage are bound to both atoms O7 and O16′′ from two cages, thus ensuring two-dimensional connectivity in the ab plane (Figure ). Two isolated [Ba(H2O)8]2+ counterions, of square antiprismatic geometry, occupy the spaces between four molecules in the layers. The average Ba−O(carboxylate) and Ba−O(water) bond lengths of 2.838(14) and 2.89(10) Å, respectively, are comparable to their counterparts from the Cambridge Structural Database (Version 5.30), 2.81(11) and 2.82(8) Å. The channels are no more free, being obstructed by the [Ba(H2O)8]2+ groups. The solvent water molecules are either located in the layers and hydrogen bonded to two cages and the aqua ligands of the bridging barium atoms or they are bridging carboxylate groups in one layer and [Ba(H2O)8]2+ ions in the next layer.

Although it was attempted in the present system primarily to try to get better crystals, it resulted in the isolation of compound 2, which comprises the octanuclear cage [(UO2)8L12]8-, now devoid of remaining protons and with bond lengths and angles identical to those in 1, but which is now part of a cation-bridged two-dimensional assembly. Two barium atoms per octanuclear cage are bound to both atoms O7 and O16'' from two cages, thus ensuring two-dimensional connectivity in the ab plane (Figure ). Two isolated [Ba(H2O)8]2+ counterions, of square antiprismatic geometry, occupy the spaces between four molecules in the layers. The average Ba-O(carboxylate) and Ba-O(water) bond lengths of 2.838(14) and 2.89(10) Å, respectively, are comparable to their counterparts from the Cambridge Structural Database (Version 5.30), 2.81(11) and 2.82(8) Å. The channels are no more free, being obstructed by the [Ba(H2O)8]2+ groups. The solvent water molecules are either located in the layers and hydrogen bonded to two cages and the aqua ligands of the bridging barium atoms or they are bridging carboxylate groups in one layer and [Ba(H2O)8]2+ ions in the next layer.

Solvent molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted. Atoms are represented as spheres of arbitrary radii. a axis horizontal, b axis vertical in both views.

elements.content: Complexes 1 and 2 provide novel examples of the nanosized cages which can be obtained with uranyl ions and curved ditopic ligands and they are the first such examples to be obtained under hydrothermal conditions and to be homoleptic, since the previous cases included μ-peroxo bridging ions in addition to the dicarboxylate or bis(catecholate) ligands. Moreover, the present complexes present built-in chirality, which was not the case of the former examples. While the pseudocubic cages in 1 and 2 are analogous to those present in the homoleptic, three-dimensional uranyl complex with 1,2,3,4-cyclobutanetetracarboxylate, the tetradentate nature of the latter ligand is conducive to the formation of a polymeric material, whereas the camphorate cage can be isolated as a molecular species. The cavity size is nearly the same in both cases, as well as the diameter of the channels (although two types of channels exist in the three-dimensional compound, due to the coexistence of two different subunits). The novelty of the present complex is that it can be used as a building unit in an alkaline-earth-bridged two-dimensional polymer. The arrangement of the octanuclear cages and the unit cell parameters are retained when going from the molecular species to the polymer, the additional cations being located in the intermolecular spaces present in 1 (some of them occupied by bridging, hydrogen bonded water molecules). The present polymer can thus be viewed as a novel example of the “supramolecular building block approach” to the synthesis of metal−organic frameworks, with previous examples also involving cubic subunits.
elements.clean_text: Complexes 1 and 2 provide novel examples of the nanosized cages which can be obtained with uranyl ions and curved ditopic ligands and they are the first such examples to be obtained under hydrothermal conditions and to be homoleptic, since the previous cases included μ-peroxo bridging ions in addition to the dicarboxylate or bis(catecholate) ligands. Moreover, the present complexes present built-in chirality, which was not the case of the former examples. While the pseudocubic cages in 1 and 2 are analogous to those present in the homoleptic, three-dimensional uranyl complex with 1,2,3,4-cyclobutanetetracarboxylate, the tetradentate nature of the latter ligand is conducive to the formation of a polymeric material, whereas the camphorate cage can be isolated as a molecular species. The cavity size is nearly the same in both cases, as well as the diameter of the channels (although two types of channels exist in the three-dimensional compound, due to the coexistence of two different subunits). The novelty of the present complex is that it can be used as a building unit in an alkaline-earth-bridged two-dimensional polymer. The arrangement of the octanuclear cages and the unit cell parameters are retained when going from the molecular species to the polymer, the additional cations being located in the intermolecular spaces present in 1 (some of them occupied by bridging, hydrogen bonded water molecules). The present polymer can thus be viewed as a novel example of the "supramolecular building block approach" to the synthesis of metal-organic frameworks, with previous examples also involving cubic subunits.

elements.content: Tables of crystal data, atomic positions and displacement parameters, anisotropic displacement parameters, and bond lengths and bond angles in CIF format; displacement ellipsoid plots. This information is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Tables of crystal data, atomic positions and displacement parameters, anisotropic displacement parameters, and bond lengths and bond angles in CIF format; displacement ellipsoid plots. This information is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Synthesis of 1. (1R,3S)-(+)-Camphoric acid (40 mg, 0.20 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (100 mg, 0.20 mmol), 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO, 22 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding yellow crystals of complex 1 within three days (61 mg, 77% based on the acid). Anal. Calcd for C120H200O76U8: C, 30.26; H, 4.23. Found: C, 30.28; H, 5.29%. Synthesis of 2. (1R,3S)-(+)-Camphoric acid (20 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), Ba(CH3COO)2 (26 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (3 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding yellow crystals of complex 2 in low yield within three days.
elements.clean_text:
References

Synthesis of 1. (1R,3S)-(+)-Camphoric acid (40 mg, 0.20 mmol), UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (100 mg, 0.20 mmol), 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO, 22 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding yellow crystals of complex 1 within three days (61 mg, 77% based on the acid). Anal. Calcd for C120H200O76U8: C, 30.26; H, 4.23. Found: C, 30.28; H, 5.29%. Synthesis of 2. (1R,3S)-(+)-Camphoric acid (20 mg, 0.10 mmol), UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), Ba(CH3COO)2 (26 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (3 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding yellow crystals of complex 2 in low yield within three days.

elements.content: Crystallographic data were collected at 100(2) K (1) or 150(2) K (2) on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area-detector diffractometer and processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected with SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were not found and the carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. The drawings were done with ORTEP-3/POV-Ray and Balls & Sticks. Crystal data for 1: C120H200O76U8, M = 4763.04, tetragonal, space group I4, a = b = 17.9223(6), c = 33.2705(19) Å, V = 10686.8(8) Å3, Z = 2. Refinement of 470 parameters on 9497 independent reflections out of 74327 measured reflections (R int = 0.051) led to R1 = 0.051, wR2 = 0.147, S = 1.009, Δρmin = −1.44, Δρmax = 1.14 e Å−3. Crystal data for 2: C120H224Ba4O92U8, M = 5592.59, tetragonal, space group I4, a = b = 17.7501(5), c = 33.4349(12) Å, V = 10534.2(6) Å3, Z = 2. Refinement of 529 parameters on 9982 independent reflections out of 101122 measured reflections (R int = 0.048) led to R1 = 0.050, wR2 = 0.135, S = 1.027, Δρmin = −1.23, Δρmax = 1.72 e Å−3.

cln_elements.content: Crystallographic data were collected at 100(2) K (1) or 150(2) K (2) on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area-detector diffractometer and processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected with SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were not found and the carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. The drawings were done with ORTEP-3/POV-Ray and Balls & Sticks. Crystal data for 1: C120H200O76U8, M = 4763.04, tetragonal, space group I4, a = b = 17.9223(6), c = 33.2705(19) Å, V = 10686.8(8) Å3, Z = 2. Refinement of 470 parameters on 9497 independent reflections out of 74327 measured reflections (R int = 0.051) led to R1 = 0.051, wR2 = 0.147, S = 1.009, Δρmin = −1.44, Δρmax = 1.14 e Å−3. Crystal data for 2: C120H224Ba4O92U8, M = 5592.59, tetragonal, space group I4, a = b = 17.7501(5), c = 33.4349(12) Å, V = 10534.2(6) Å3, Z = 2. Refinement of 529 parameters on 9982 independent reflections out of 101122 measured reflections (R int = 0.048) led to R1 = 0.050, wR2 = 0.135, S = 1.027, Δρmin = −1.23, Δρmax = 1.72 e Å−3.
cln_elements.clean_text: Crystallographic data were collected at 100(2) K (1) or 150(2) K (2) on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area-detector diffractometer and processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected with SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were not found and the carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. The drawings were done with ORTEP-3/POV-Ray and Balls & Sticks. Crystal data for 1: C120H200O76U8, M = 4763.04, tetragonal, space group I4, a = b = 17.9223(6), c = 33.2705(19) Å, V = 10686.8(8) Å3, Z = 2. Refinement of 470 parameters on 9497 independent reflections out of 74327 measured reflections (R int = 0.051) led to R1 = 0.051, wR2 = 0.147, S = 1.009, Δρmin = -1.44, Δρmax = 1.14 e Å-3. Crystal data for 2: C120H224Ba4O92U8, M = 5592.59, tetragonal, space group I4, a = b = 17.7501(5), c = 33.4349(12) Å, V = 10534.2(6) Å3, Z = 2. Refinement of 529 parameters on 9982 independent reflections out of 101122 measured reflections (R int = 0.048) led to R1 = 0.050, wR2 = 0.135, S = 1.027, Δρmin = -1.23, Δρmax = 1.72 e Å-3.

metadata.title: A Nanosized Uranyl Camphorate Cage and its Use as a Building Unit in a Metal−Organic Framework
